data.title: portrait of princess victoria by victoria
data.meta_description: Unsigned Carte-de-visite Portrait Photograph, by Hills & Saunders, (1840-1901, Empress Frederick of Germany, wife of Friedrich III, eldest child of Queen Victoria & mother of Kaiser Wilhelm II)] and her daughter SOPHIE (Dorothea Ulrike Alice, 1870-1932, Princess of Prussia, wife of King Constantine I of Greece)] by [VICTORIA.  showing the Crown Princess three quarter length, three quarter face, in a dress with a richly embroidered hem, leaning over with a smile forming towards the right of the image to hold Princess Sophie, who is perched full length, nearly full face, on a stool on a studio table, in a white dress and a hair ribbon, her left arm round her mother's neck, between them they are holding a book on Sophie's lap, 4¼" x 2½", no place, no date, circa   Hills & Saunders was one of the ...
data.text:
Show Details

Description:

showing the Crown Princess three quarter length, three quarter face, in a dress with a richly embroidered hem, leaning over with a smile forming towards the right of the image to hold Princess Sophie, who is perched full length, nearly full face, on a stool on a studio table, in a white dress and a hair ribbon, her left arm round her mother's neck, between them they are holding a book on Sophie's lap, 4¼" x 2½", no place, no date, circa Hills & Saunders was one of the leading Victorian photographic firms, started as a partnership between Robert Hills & John Henry Saunders. They were social photographers with studios at different times in London, Harrow & Eton & Rugby, Oxford & Cambridge and Aldershot & Sandhurst. They were successful photographers to the royal family.

Show Details

Description:

showing them all full length, the Crown Princess seated, nearly full face, with her right hand thoughfully to her cheek, in a satin dress, Princess Sophie in the left of the image is seated in profile reading a book on her mother's knee, while Princess Margarete stands nearly full face to the camera, her right hand on her mother's shoulder, in a velvet dress with white sleeve patches matching her sister's, 4" x 2½", no place, no date, circa very lightly browned but an attractive image

Show Details

Description:

made from photographic images from three quarter to full face & length, in two rows, Prince Albert in the centre of the back row, with Queen Victoria on his left, 2¼" x 3½" in margins 2½" x 4", no place, no date, the images circa Back row:: Princess Helena, in profile to the right, a shawl over her skirt which has a battlement stripe; the Prince of Wales, in military uniform; Prince Albert; the Queen, in profile to the left; Prince Alfred, in midshipman's short dinner jacket; Princess Alice, in profile to the left, in a light coloured dress. Front row: Princess Victoria, in cloak and bonnet; Prince Leopold, full face in highland dress; Princess Beatrice, in a white child's dress with wide skirt, her hair in a garland; Princess Louise, dressed like Princess Helena; and Prince Arthur, in profile to the left, one foot behind the other, in highland dress.

Show Details

Description:

of Berlin, showing them head and touching shoulders, three quarter face towards the right, Princess Alice with a plain hair band, the Crown Princess with a more elaborate jewelled one, two striking character studies not often seen together by this date, soft-edged image approximately 1¾" x 1½" on card mount 4" x 2½", no place, no date, circa neat early identification in top blank portion of image With the contemporary label on the verso of P.E. Chappuis, of Fleet Street, 'Photographer, Reflector Patentee, Importer and Manufacturer of Amusing and Scientific Novelties'. Chappuis' reflectors were designed to bring daylight into dark basements.

Show Details

Description:

showing her mounted side-saddle, full length, in near profile, in hat and crinoline skirt, Brown full face, full length in highland dress, holding the horse's bridle, with below Princess Helena in profile, kneeling facing her attentive dog, 3½" x 2½", no place, no date but Osborne, Isle of Wight, When the Queen went into mourning in 1861, fears were entertained for her health, and to give her exercise, John Brown and her favourite pony were brought down from Balmoral. While she had no one now to call her 'Victoria', John Brown, who at least addressed her at times as 'Wumman', was the nearest thing. After his mother's death, Edward VII ordered all mementoes of Brown at Osborne to be destroyed.

Show Details

Description:

below the image and dated, showing her head and shoulders, three quarter face, in a collared blouse with a pattern of three shamrocks repeated, 6½" x 4¼", no place,

Show Details

Description:

showing her head and shoulders, full length, full face, in a long white gown with appliqué work, her left hand on a chair, a bouquet of roses in her right, 8" x 4¼" on card mount 9¼" x 5½", no place, 14th May a little light spotting, small defects in edge of mount

Show Details

Description:

showing her three quarters length in typical twenties costume, 9" x 6½", no place, (London) no date, The Queen visited England for the wedding of the future George VI and the Queen Mother. By this time her marriage was in tatters and the monarchy was ready to topple. Sadly, when she did leave Spain in 1931 she is meant to have said "I thought I had done so well".
